sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: The genus Panaspis in Angola is represented by four species, most of them part of taxonomically and nomenclaturally challenging species-complexes. We present a taxonomic revision of the group in the region and describe one new species, Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. , endemic to the lowland areas of the Namibe province , southwestern Angola . Phylogenetic analysis using a combination of mitochondrial (16S, cyt b ) and nucleares (RAG1, PDC) markers, as well as morphological and meristic data support the recognition of the new species. In addition, these data support the presence of nominotypical Panaspis cabindae , P. wahlbergi and P. maculicollis in Angola . Reexamination of the Angolan population of P. breviceps was based on morphological analysis, as no molecular data from Angola is available for this species. According to our results, this population likely represents the nominotypical form, but due to its complex taxonomic and nomenclatural history and the lack of molecular data, this population needs to be reconsidered when molecular data become available. The description of a new species and revision of the Angolan Panaspis contributes to a better understanding of the true species richness of the Angolan herpetofauna, as well as to understanding the major biogeographic patterns of the region. A key to Angolan Panaspis species is also presented.
Key words: endemism; Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. ; southwestern Africa; cryptic species; taxonomy
Resumo

O género Panaspis está representado em Angola por quatro espécies diferentes, na sua maioria fazendo parte de complexos de espécies particularmente desafiantes a nível taxonómico e nomenclatural. Apresentamos uma revisão taxonómica detalhada do grupo na região e descrevemos uma nova espécie, Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. , endémica das áreas de baixa elevação da província do Namibe , sudoeste de Angola . Análises filogenéticas utilizando uma combinação de marcadores mitocondriais (16S, cyt b ) e moleculares (RAG1, PDC), bem como dados morfológicos e de escamas, suportam o reconhecimento da nova espécie. Para além disso, os dados suportam a presença em Angola de formas nominotípicas das espécies Panaspis cabindae , P. wahlbergi e P. maculicollis . Novos exames da população Angolana de Panaspis breviceps foram realizadas apenas com base em análises morfológicas externas, visto que não existem dados moleculares desta espécie para Angola . De acordo com os nossos resultados, esta população pode representar a forma nominotípica, mas devido à sua complexa história taxonómica e nomenclatural e à inexistência de dados moleculares, a identidade desta população deverá ser novamente revista quando estes dados se encontrarem disponíveis. A descrição da nova espécie e a revisão das restantes espécies de Panaspis Angolanas
contribuí para um melhor conhecimento dos verdadeiros números da herpetofauna do país, bem como para começar a deslindar os principais padrões biogeográficos da região. Uma chave dicotómica para as espécies que ocorrem em Angola é também apresentada.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The genus PanaspisCope, 1868 , whose members are commonly known as African snake-eyed skinks, has been a subject of renewed interest in recent years, with a molecular-based phylogeny (
Medina et al. 2016
), and the description of three new species (
Soares et al. 2018
;
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
;
Kilunda et al. 2019
) in the last three years. The generic allocation of the different species traditionally regarded as members of Panaspis sensu lato was a subject of intense debate and different interpretations during the second half of the twentieth century and first years of the present one ( Fuhn 1969 , 1972 ; Perret 1973 , 1975 ; Greer 1974 ;
Schmitz et al. 2005
;
Jesus et al. 2007
;
Medina et al. 2016
). Brief reviews of the taxonomic and nomenclatural histories of Panaspis were presented by
Soares et al. (2018)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
. Currently, the revison of the ge nus byMedina et al. (2016) , Panaspis sensu stricto includes 19 described species, namely P. africana (Gray, 1845)
, P . annobonensis Fuhn, 1973
, P. breviceps ( Peters, 1873 )
, P. burgeoni ( De Witte, 1933 )
, P. cabindae (Bocage, 1866)
, P. duruarum ( Monard, 1949 )
, P. helleri ( Loveridge, 1932 )
, P. maculicollisJacobsen & Broadley, 2000 , P. massaiensis ( Angel, 1924 )
, P. megalurus ( Nieden, 1923 )
, P. namibianaCeríaco, Branch & Bauer, 2018 , P. nimbaensisAngel, 1944 , P. seydeli ( De Witte, 1933 )
, P. tancredi ( Boulenger, 1909 )
, P. thomensis Ceríaco et al. 2018 in Soares et al. 2018
, P. tsavoensis Kilunda et al. 2019
, P. togoensis ( Werner, 1902 )
, P. wahlbergi ( Smith, 1849 )
, and P. wilsoni ( Werner, 1914 )
. However, it is also recognized that a considerable number of cryptic species within the genus still await description (
Medina et al. 2016
;
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
;
Kilunda et al. 2019
).

Currently four species of Panaspis are recognized for Angola (see
Marques et al. 2018
): Panaspis breviceps ( Peters, 1873 )
, only known from a few specimens from the escarpment areas of Kwanza Sul and Kwanza Norte provinces, in the Angolan Escarpment; Panaspis cabindae (Bocage, 1866)
, extending from central Africa to the central highlands in Angola , effectively reaching its southern limit outside of the xeric zone; Panaspis maculicollisJacobsen and Broadley, 2000 , entering Angola in the south-eastern province of Cuando-Cubango; and a representative of the Panaspis wahlbergi species complex on the central plateau of Angola .

Panaspis cabindae , which was originally described from the Cabinda enclave, northwestern Angola , is the most widely recorded species of Panaspis in the country (
Marques et al. 2018
). The species is known from southwestern Democratic Republic of the Congo , the Cabinda enclave and northern regions of Angola , extending south through the Angolan escarpment, and being present in the lower elevation margins of the escarpment as far south as Capangombe, in Namibe Province (
Marques et al. 2018
). This wide distribution is supported by the molecular evidence presented by
Medina et al. (2016)
, who showed that specimens from Western Democratic Republic of Congo to southern Angola nested together in a well-supported clade.

The first record of P. maculicollis for the country was presented by
Conradie et al. (2016)
, based on a single specimen collected in the southeastern tip of Cuando-Cubango Province. The taxonomic identity of this specimen was confirmed by
Medina et al. (2016)
. This remains the only verified record of this species for Angola .

Bocage (1895) was the first to note the presence of P. wahlbergi - type animals in the country, based on two specimens from Caconda and Cahata, in the highlands of Huíla and Bié provinces, respectively. Boulenger (1905) reported specimens from an unspecific locality “between Benguela and Bihe” (currently Benguela and Bié provinces). No additional records of P. wahlbergi in Angola have been published since these early contributions, but some Angolan specimens assignable to this taxon exist in several natural history collections worldwide. More recently, specimens morphologically assignable to the P. wahlbergi species complex were collected in southern Bié Province near Mumbué municipality in June 2019 .
Branch et al. (2019a)
suggested that the Angolan populations of P. wahlbergi potentially represented an undescribed species within the broad P. wahlbergi species complex, an idea that appears likely in light of the study of
Medina et al. (2016)
, which showed that the species was composed of at least nine cryptic and still undescribed taxa across its entire range.

No records of Panaspis exist in the literature from lower elevations of southwestern Angola , namely in the more xeric areas of Namibe Province . In the course of recent herpetological surveys in the country, specimens were collected in Virei and Maungo municipalities, central Namibe Province , which are morphologically most similar to the newly described species Panaspis namibiana (a member of the P. maculicollis group) known only from the central and northern regions of neighboring Namibia (Ceríaco et al. 2018).

Although
Medina et al. (2016)
assessed some Angolan material, they did not include any Angolan representatives of the wahlbergi , breviceps or namibiana groups. This material is essential to address the questions regarding the taxonomic identity and biogeographic affinities of the Angolan populations of the different Panaspis taxa. Taking advantage of the backbone molecular phylogeny provided by
Medina et al. (2016)
and using newly collected molecular, morphological and coloration data, we taxonomically review the Angolan populations of the genus, provide a key for the species in the country, and present new data on its natural history. Our analyses support the distinctiveness of the newly found population of Panaspis cf. namibiana from Namibe Province , which we describe as a new species. Some notes on the biogeographic implications of the new findings for both the Panaspis group but also overall regional herpetofauna are also presented.

sec.p: Newly collected specimens were preserved in 10% buffered formalin in the field and were subsequently transferred to 70–75% ethanol. Liver tissue was removed before formalin fixation and preserved in 95% ethanol. For mensural and meristic comparisons, we examined other Angolan Panaspis specimens deposited in the collections at California Academy of Sciences ( CAS ), San Francisco, California , USA , Field Museum of Natural History ( FMNH ), Chicago, Illinois , USA ; Museum for Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts , USA ( MCZ ), Florida Museum of Natural History ( FLMNH ), University of Florida , Gainesville, Florida , USA ; Carnegie Museum of Natural History (CM), Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania , USA , American Museum of Natural History ( AMNH ), New York , New York , USA ; University of Texas El-Paso Herpetological collection ( UTEP ), El-Paso, Texas , USA ; Port Elizabeth Museum/Bayworld ( PEM ), Port Elizabeth, South Africa , Ditsong National Museum of Natural History ( TM ), Pretoria, South Africa ; Instituto de Investigação Científica Tropical ( IICT ), Lisbon , Portugal ; Museu de História Natural e da Ciência da Universidade do Porto (MHNC-UP), Porto , Portugal ; Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle ( MNHN ), Paris, France ; Naturhistorisches Museum ( NHMW ), Wien , Austria ; and the Natural History Museum ( BMNH ), London, United Kingdom .

Morphological methods. Specimens were measured with a digital caliper to the nearest 0.1 mm . Lepidosis was examined under a stereo-microscope. Scale nomenclature, scales counts and measurements used in the description follow Broadley (2000), Jacobsen & Broadley (2000) ,
Soares et al. (2018)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
. We measured the following 23 characters: snout–vent length (SVL), from the snout to the vent; tail length (TL), from anal plate to tip of tail, measured only in specimens with complete original tails; head length (HL), from tip of snout to anterior tympanum border; head height ( HH ), from the base of the maxilla to the top of head; head width (HW), at the widest part of the maxilla; eye-diameter (ED); eye-tympanum distance ( ET ); eye-snout distance (ES), from the front of the eye to the tip of the snout; length of the arm (LA); length of the forearm (LFA); length of the leg (LL); length of the foreleg (LFL); distance between limbs (LD), minimum distance between the insertion of the anterior and posterior limbs; number of scale rows at midbody ( MSR ); number of paravertebral scales (SAD), from the nuchal (excluded from count) to base of the tail; number of scales ventrally (SAV), from the mental (excluded from count) to the anal plate (excluded); number of subdigital scales under Finger-IV (LUFF); number of subdigital scales under Toe-IV (LUFT); number of supralabials (SL), with those widened in subocular position indicated between brackets; number of supraciliaries (SC); nature of contact between parietals (CP); nature of contact between frontoparietals (CFP); nature of contact between prefrontals (CPF); nature of contact between prefrontal and preoculars (CPF/PO). Finally, coloration pattern was reported, and high-resolution photographs of preserved specimens taken. These data were compared with relevant literature on the group ( Perret 1973 , 1975 ; Jacobsen & Broadley 2000 ;
Soares et al. 2018
;
Ceríaco et al. 2018a
) and comparative material of congeners occurring in southern and southwestern Africa, namely P. cabindae , P. wahlbergi , P. maculicolis and P. namibiana . All specimens examined in this study are listed in the type and additional material sections of each species’ taxonomic account. Locality data are reported in the form of decimal degrees and use the WGS 84 map datum. Older (non-GPS) records are mostly derived from
Marques et al. (2018)
and have been georeferenced using GEOLocate web application (https://www.geo-locate.org). Elevations are all reported as meters above sea level.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Angolan Panaspis included in our phylogenetic analysis belong to four separate species (
). Angolan representatives for two of these, P. maculicollis and P. cabindae , were previously included in the data set of
Medina et al. (2016)
. None of the additional samples we sequenced belong to P. maculicollis , and this species is still documented in Angola only from Cuando-Cubango in the far southeast. Most of the samples we sequenced are assignable to P. cabindae , which is broadly distributed across the western highlands from the far north all the way to Namibe Province in the south, often with little genetic variation among samples. Our analysis provides genetic verification for two other species of Panaspis in Angola . One specimen from Bicuar National Park in south-central Angola was tentatively identified as Panaspis aff. namibiana in
Butler et al. (2019)
but actually represents Panaspis wahlbergi . Finally, four samples from Namibe province in southwestern Angola are sister to the recently described species P. namibiana . These Namibe samples are genetically distinct, however, displaying 11% pairwise cyt b sequence divergence from P. namibiana and 12% or more from other species in the P. maculicollis complex. ( Table 3 ).

Mensural and meristic data are presented in Table 4 . Genetic data in combination with morphology lead us to recognize five species of Panaspis in Angola , one of which we describe as a new species. We adopt the general lineage species concept ( de Queiroz 1999 ) and recognize species based on a combination of characters suggesting evolutionary independence. The five taxa of Panaspis occurring in Angola differ from each other and from other African species, in several consistent morphological characters, and they are identified through the key presented below. Detailed diagnoses for the different forms, as well as extensive nomenclatural reviews, are given in the taxonomic accounts below.

The species was described by Peters (1873) as Euprepes ( Euprepes Mabuia ) breviceps based on specimens from Gabon and “ Kamerun ” [= Cameroon ] collected, respectively, by Henry Hugh Higgins and Anton Reichenow. Two syntypes ( ZMB 6303 from Gabon ,
, and ZMB 8017 from “ Kamerun ”] are still extant in the collections of the ZMB . Fuhn (1972) claimed the presence of three additional syntypes in the collections of the BMNH ( BMNH 1902.11.12.9–11). As noted by
Bauer et al. (2003)
, two other specimens from Cameroon ( ZMB 8313), also collected by Reichenow in Cameroon , do not belong to the type series.

A more complex case has been that of Panaspis togoensis ( Werner, 1902 )
. This species was described by Werner (1902) based on one specimen collected by Arnold Voelschow in “Deustch-Togo (Atakpame)” [= Atakpamé, Togo ]. The taxonomic identity of togoensis has historically been problematic, with some authors considering it as a subspecies of breviceps ( Loveridge 1952 ; Hoogmoed 1980 ), others considering it as incertae sedis ( Fuhn 1972 ), and Perret (1975) even considering it as a junior synonym of Panaspis kitsoni ( Boulenger, 1913 )
. These taxonomic uncertainties were partially solved by
Schmitz et al. (2005)
and
Medina et al. (2016)
, who demonstrated that breviceps and togoensis are in fact two well-separated species, both basal to the remaining southern African Panaspis . This confusion is a good example of the taxonomic doubts surrounding the placement of P . breviceps within the group as a whole. The difficulties of determining correct generic placement are evident from the different generic allocations used by the authors who described the species and its synonyms, but it is perfectly summarized by Müller (1910) , who considered breviceps as belonging to Lygosoma , and noted that “in determining these specimens [of breviceps ], I was for quite some time in the dark about whether I had a Lygosoma or a Mabuia in front of me.” Fuhn (1969 , 1972 ), Perret (1973) and Greer (1974) placed the species in Panaspis , but Broadley (1989) suggested that the species was a member of the subgenus Lacertaspis , within Leptosiaphos . It was once again allocated to Panaspis by
Schmitz et al. (2005)
. While this decision was followed by
Medina et al. (2016)

Despite the doubts regarding its generic allocation, it may be inferred from the data presented by
Medina et al. (2016)
that what is currently considered as P. breviceps is clearly composed of two separated lineages, one represented in their study by a single specimen from Byonga, South Kivu, eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo , and another one from Cameroon . It is evident that a revision of Central and Western African Panaspis is much needed, not only to solve present taxonomic uncertainties regarding some taxa, but also to determine whether cryptic diversity occurs within the group.

The only records that exist for Angola refer to a series of five specimens from “Congulu”, collected for the BMNH by Karl Jordan (one of the specimens was later exchanged to the MCZ ; Parker 1936 ). Two other specimens were collected by Gerd Henrich in “Roça Canzele” in 1954 for the FMNH (one of the specimens was later exchanged to the MCZ ). Parker (1936) provided limited morphological data about the specimens from Congulu, noting only that the specimens did not “appear to differ from those found in the Cameroon-Gaboon area, though the number of scales about the body [MSR] may be somewhat lower” as “they vary from 30 to 34” while “the known range of breviceps (including batesi Boul.
) is from 32 to 38”. Perret (1973) , after the examination of 80 specimens , presented a similar range of 32 to 38 MSR. The same range was presented by
Trape et al. (2012)
.

Our analysis of a subset of these specimens ( FMNH 74297 –
; MCZ R- 110306 , 112221 ) did not find any outstanding external morphological differences between the Angolan population and the Central/West Africa populations, except, as already noted by Parker (1936) , a slightly lower number of MSR (see Table 4 ). The morphological similarity and the lack of molecular data from the Angolan population precludes us from testing its relationships with the Central/West African P. breviceps populations.

Diagnosis.Panaspis aff. breviceps can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring in Angola and surroundings region by having 1) presence of supranasals; 2) movable lower eyelids; 3) frontoparietals separated; 4) dorsum brown, with four very longitudinal stripes composed of white and black dots; 5) presence of a large lateral dark band on the flanks of females and juveniles; 6) 30 to 34 midbody scales rows.

Habitat and Natural History notes. Nothing is known about the ecology and natural history of this species in Angola . The habitat of the region in which it occurs is characterized by humid fog forests, dominated by Celtis , Albizia and Morus trees in Congulu and a forest and savannah mosaic dominated by Annona , Combretum , Piliostigma trees and Andropogon and Hyparrhenia shrubs in Roça Canzele (respectively, vegetation type 3 and 13 sensu Grandvaux-Barbosa 1973). Perret (1973) noted that P. breviceps is a “common and characteristic” equatorial forest species, that is usually found in humid areas, such as near marshes and streams. According to Perret (1973) females usually produce two, sometimes three, elongated ( 11 mm ) eggs.

In Angola , the species enters the extreme southeastern tip of Cuando-Cubango Province, however it is probable that it is more widespread in the province, and similar habitat extends into Moxico Province (
).

P. wahlbergi was originally described as Cryptoblepharus wahlbergi by Smith (1849) based on specimens from the “Country to the eastward of the Cape Colony,” later restricted to KwaZulu-Natal Province , South Africa , by FitzSimons (1937) . Similar to all other members of the genus, the species has a complex taxonomic history, especially regarding its genetic allocation (for a review of its taxonomic and nomenclatural history see
Schmitz et al. 2005
and
Medina et al. 2016
). The first records of this species for Angola were provided by Bocage (1895) , who noted specimens collected by J.A.O. de Anchieta from Cahata and Caconda, in the higher elevation areas of Benguela and Huíla provinces, respectively. As he had done with P. cabindae , Bocage (1895) provided a detailed illustration of Angolan P. wahlbergi (
). Boulenger (1905) referred to this species specimens collected “between Benguella and Bihé” [between what it is currently understood as Benguela and Bié provinces] by the British explorer William John Ansorge ( 1850–1913 ). These are the only published records of the species for Angola , although some other specimens assignable to the species were collected in the country during the twentieth century and deposited in the collections of Portuguese (IICT), North American (CAS, FMNH) and South African (TM) museums. More recently the species has been relocated in the country.
Baptista et al. (2018)
reported the presence of Panaspis sp. in theTundavala area.
Butler et al. (2019)
reported one specimen from Bicuar National Park, which they mistakenly labeled as P. aff. namibiana . Other specimens were recently collected by the authors LMPC and MPM in southeastern Bié Province .

Marques et al. (2018)
and Branch et al. (2019) referred to the central Angolan populations of P. wahlbergi as P. aff. wahlbergi , suggesting doubts about its conspecificity with the nominotypical form, and even suggesting that the Angolan population may represent a different taxon (
Branch et al. 2019a
). However, contrary to what
Medina et al. (2016)
demonstrated for the eastern African populations, where a high level of cryptic diversity exists, and to the suspicions of
Marques et al. (2018)
and Branch et al. (2019), our results unambiguously place the central Angolan population as conspecific with nominotypic wahlbergi . The presence in the country of additional undescribed wahlbergi -like lineages cannot be excluded, as Bittencourt-Silva (2019) recently reported the presence of one of these lineages (“ Panaspis sp. Katanga 2” sensu
Medina et al. 2016
) in northwestern Zambia , not far from the Angolan border. Specimens from Calombe-Luso, Moxico Province, (IICT 268–1959 and 276–1959) could potentially belong to this lineage as well. Further sampling in the eastern regions of the country is needed to address this possibility.

).

Diagnosis.Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from other members of the genus by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a dorsolateral light stripe extending approximately to midbody, accompanied by a thinner stripe composed by black dots band starting on the temporals and extending to the base of the tail; 5) presence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) absence of a white ventrolateral stripe; 7) 23 to 24 midbody scales rows.

Description of the holotype .
Unsexed subadult in good condition, but with a regenerated tail. Arrangement and relative size of head, body and tail scales typical for Panaspis . Robust, cylindrical body with well-developed pentadactyl limbs. Fore- and hind-limbs do not overlap when adpressed against the body. SVL 32.6 mm , tail regenerated. Head length 6.2 mm , with relatively acuminate snout (HL 172% HW). Other relevant measurements are presented in Table 5 . Rostral wider than high, and visible from above. Nasals widely separated behind rostral by frontonasal. Frontonasal acuminate anteriorly, wider than long. Nostrils small, set posteriorly in the nasals bordering the postnasal. Prefrontals in contact with one another, almost pentagonal, contacting loreals, first supraocular, and frontal. Two loreals, the posterior margins of the largest loreal bordering the preocular, which is higher than wide. Frontal length shorter than distance between anterior tip of frontal and tip of snout; frontal in contact with prefrontals anteriorly, the first supraocular, and frontoparietals. Frontoparietals fused, in contact with the frontal, three supraoculars, parietals and interparietal. Frontoparietal plus interparietal length 2.2 times length of the frontal. Interparietal pentagonal with visible parietal foramen in anterior part; parietals about the same width of that of the frontoparietals and contacting each other at the anterior point of the interparietal. Parietals in contact. A pair of large, broad nuchals collectively bordered by a total of eight dorsals. Supraoculars three. Supraciliaries four (left side) and four (right side), third largest. Pretemporals two. Tympanum visible, approximately one seventh the height of the eye. Supralabials six, the fifth and sixth being the suboculars. Ablepharine eye. Infralabials five. Postmental bordering five scales (mental, two primary chin-shields, and one infralabial on each side). Ventral scales smooth. MSR 23, SAD 56, SAV 57. Limbs with five digits; scales on soles of hands and feet smooth. Relative length of digits of manus III>IV>II>VI relative length of digits of pes IV>III>II=V>I. Finger-IV scales 9 (right side), Toe-IV scales 15 (right side). Tail long, robust and tapering smoothly.

Both in life and preservative, background color of flanks and upper side of head, neck, dorsum, legs and tail is coppery brown, with a darker dot in the anterior part of each scale. Posteriorly the tail is lighter, with disjunct dark speckles. A beige stripe, less than one scale wide, limited by the dorsal background color above and by a thin stripe of darker brown below (especially evident under the anterior part of eye), extends from the temporals and runs along the insertion of the arms. Areas below the dark brown stripe become lighter, until they reach the ventral side, which is beige. Presence of rows of light spots on the neck. Supralabials light beige anteriorly and posteriorly, with strong coppery brown markings in the middle. This pattern extends to the infralabials. Venter uniformly light-beige, as are the palmar regions of hands and feet.

Variation. Variaton in scalation and body measurements of the paratypes of Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. is reported in Table 5 . The majority of the paratypes agree entirely with the holotype , except regarding the contact between the prefrontals, which are separated in paratypes CAS 263325 and 263326.

Comparison with other south and southwestern African Panaspis .
As the molecular data provide evidence of the independence of the P. mocamedensis sp. nov. lineage from all other taxa, we here restrict our morphological comparisons to those named congeners occurring in Namibia and Angola . The extreme morphological conservatism of Panaspis limits diagnostic characters for most species (except P. cabindae and P. aff. breviceps ) to subtle features, chiefly related to coloration pattern. Comparing P. mocamedensis sp. nov. with P. cabindae and P. aff. breviceps , the newly described species can be easily distinguished by not having supranasals (present in P. cabindae ), by having an ablepharine eye (pre-ablepharine eye in P. cabindae and completely movable lower eyelids in P. aff. breviceps ), and by having the frontoparietals fused (divided in P. cabindae and in P. aff. breviceps ). In comparison with P. wahlbergi , P. mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished by its coloration, namely by the lack of the broad black lateral stripe and bordering ventrolateral white stripe extending from the supralabials through the ear to the groin (males) or terminating behind the shoulder (females). Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from P. maculicollis on the basis of the lack of black patch extending from ear to just beyond the shoulder and by having a smaller count of midbody scale rows ( 23 to 24 inP. mocamedensis sp. nov.versus typically 26 inP. maculicollis ). P. mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from the newly described P. namibiana on the basis of the presence two or three vertical or diagonal rows of white spots on the neck and by having a smaller count of midbody scale rows ( 23 to 24 inP. mocamedensis sp. nov.versus usually more than 24 inP. namibiana ).

Distribution. The newly described species is currently only known from central Namibe Province (
). It is likely that the species occurs in other regions of the province where appropriate habitat is available, but further sampling is needed to confirm its presence.

Habitat and Natural History notes. The species is terrestrial and is typically found under leaf litter or other debris. It is only known from habitats represented by mosaics of steppes and savannah dominated by Mopane trees and sandy soils (
; Grandvaux-Barbosa 1973). Specimens from Virei were captured by day, but CAS 264266 was active under debris well after sunset.

Etymology. The specific epithet “ mocamedensis ” refers to the former name of Namibe Province (Moçâmedes), to which the species is apparently endemic. We propose the English vernacular name “Moçamedes Snake-Eyed Skink” and the Portuguese vernacular name of “Lagartixa da Manta-Morta de Moçâmedes”.

Distribution. The species occurs in the southwestern region of Republic of the Congo and the Democratic Republic of the Congo , extending to all parts of northern Angolan and descending south to central and southwestern Angola through the Angolan escarpment (
).

Habitat and Natural History notes. The species is found in a wide variety of habitats, from some more coastal, Euphorbia and baobab dominated savannahs, in northwestern Angola , to typical Miombo woodland habitats (
) in the central plateau of Angola . The species appears to be absent from the more xeric and desertic areas of the southwest of Angola and northwestern Namibia , however it may possibly be found in more humid areas close to the escarpment. The species is active during the day in leaf-litter, but is rarely seen exposed.

This species was described by Jacobsen & Broadley (2000) , based on specimens from northern Limpopo and Mpumalanga provinces of South Africa , northern Botswana , northeastern Namibia , Zimbabwe , southern Zambia and central Mozambique .
Medina et al. (2016)
presented evidence that the central Namibian populations, as well as those from Mozambique and Limpopo represent undescribed species. The central Namibian population was recent- ly described by Ceríaco et al. (2018), while the other lineages await description.
Conradie et al. (2016)
presented the first record of the species for Angola , based on a single specimen collected in the southeastern tip of Cuando- Cubango Province. The taxonomic identity of this specimen was confirmed by
Medina et al. (2016)
.

Diagnosis.Panaspis maculicollis can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring in Angola by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a dorsolateral light stripe extending approximately to midbody, and a thin darker band starting on the temporals and extending to midbody; 5) presence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) absence of a white ventrolateral stripe; 7) 22 to 28 midbody scales rows (usually 26).

Distribution. The species is known from the Kalahari sand areas of northeastern Namibia , northern Botswana and western Zimbabwe . In Angola , the species enters the extreme southeastern tip of Cuando-Cubango Province, however it is probable that it is more widespread in the province, and similar habitat extends into Moxico Province (
).

Habitat and Natural History notes. A terrestrial species occupying a variety of habitats from rocky or stony hillsides to open woodland/grassland at altitudes of 220-1200 m ( Jacobsen & Broadley 2000 ). In Angola the species is known from the sparse Miombo woodlands from southeastern Moxico .
Ablepharus wahlbergii ( Boulenger 1905: 111 ; Loveridge 1957: 219)

P. wahlbergi was originally described as Cryptoblepharus wahlbergi by Smith (1849) based on specimens from the “Country to the eastward of the Cape Colony,” later restricted to KwaZulu-Natal Province , South Africa , by FitzSimons (1937) . Similar to all other members of the genus, the species has a complex taxonomic history, especially regarding its genetic allocation (for a review of its taxonomic and nomenclatural history see
Schmitz et al. 2005
and
Medina et al. 2016
). The first records of this species for Angola were provided by Bocage (1895) , who noted specimens collected by J.A.O. de Anchieta from Cahata and Caconda, in the higher elevation areas of Benguela and Huíla provinces, respectively. As he had done with P. cabindae , Bocage (1895) provided a detailed illustration of Angolan P. wahlbergi (
). Boulenger (1905) referred to this species specimens collected “between Benguella and Bihé” [between what it is currently understood as Benguela and Bié provinces] by the British explorer William John Ansorge ( 1850–1913 ). These are the only published records of the species for Angola , although some other specimens assignable to the species were collected in the country during the twentieth century and deposited in the collections of Portuguese (IICT), North American (CAS, FMNH) and South African (TM) museums. More recently the species has been relocated in the country.
Baptista et al. (2018)
reported the presence of Panaspis sp. in theTundavala area.
Butler et al. (2019)
reported one specimen from Bicuar National Park, which they mistakenly labeled as P. aff. namibiana . Other specimens were recently collected by the authors LMPC and MPM in southeastern Bié Province .

Both
Marques et al. (2018)
and Branch et al. (2019) referred to the central Angolan populations of P. wahlbergi as P. aff. wahlbergi , suggesting doubts about its conspecificity with the nominotypical form, and even suggesting that the Angolan population may represent a different taxon (
Branch et al. 2019a
). However, contrary to what
Medina et al. (2016)
demonstrated for the eastern African populations, where a high level of cryptic diversity exists, and to the suspicions of
Marques et al. (2018)
and Branch et al. (2019), our results unambiguously place the central Angolan population as conspecific with nominotypic wahlbergi . The presence in the country of additional undescribed wahlbergi -like lineages cannot be excluded, as Bittencourt-Silva (2019) recently reported the presence of one of these lineages (“ Panaspis sp. Katanga 2” sensu
Medina et al. 2016
) in northwestern Zambia , not far from the Angolan border. Specimens from Calombe-Luso, Moxico Province, (IICT 268–1959 and 276–1959) could potentially belong to this lineage as well. Further sampling in the eastern regions of the country is needed to address this possibility.

Diagnosis.Panaspis wahlbergi can be distinguished from other members of the genus occurring in Angola by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a broad black lateral band; 5) absence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) usually a presence of a white ventrolateral stripe, from supralabials to the groin; 7) 24 to 26 midbody scales rows (
).

Diagnosis.Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from other members of the genus by the following combination of characteristics: 1) absence of supranasals; 2) ablepharine eye (as defined by Greer 1974 ); 3) frontoparietals fused; 4) dorsum coppery-brown, with a dorsolateral light stripe extending approximately to midbody, accompanied by a thinner stripe composed by black dots band starting on the temporals and extending to the base of the tail; 5) presence of rows of light spots on the neck; 6) absence of a white ventrolateral stripe; 7) 23 to 24 midbody scales rows.

Description of the holotype .
Unsexed subadult in good condition, but with a regenerated tail. Arrangement and relative size of head, body and tail scales typical for Panaspis . Robust, cylindrical body with well-developed pentadactyl limbs. Fore- and hind-limbs do not overlap when adpressed against the body. SVL 32.6 mm , tail regenerated. Head length 6.2 mm , with relatively acuminate snout (HL 172% HW). Other relevant measurements are presented in Table 5 . Rostral wider than high, and visible from above. Nasals widely separated behind rostral by frontonasal. Frontonasal acuminate anteriorly, wider than long. Nostrils small, set posteriorly in the nasals bordering the postnasal. Prefrontals in contact with one another, almost pentagonal, contacting loreals, first supraocular, and frontal. Two loreals, the posterior margins of the largest loreal bordering the preocular, which is higher than wide. Frontal length shorter than distance between anterior tip of frontal and tip of snout; frontal in contact with prefrontals anteriorly, the first supraocular, and frontoparietals. Frontoparietals fused, in contact with the frontal, three supraoculars, parietals and interparietal. Frontoparietal plus interparietal length 2.2 times length of the frontal. Interparietal pentagonal with visible parietal foramen in anterior part; parietals about the same width of that of the frontoparietals and contacting each other at the anterior point of the interparietal. Parietals in contact. A pair of large, broad nuchals collectively bordered by a total of eight dorsals. Supraoculars three. Supraciliaries four (left side) and four (right side), third largest. Pretemporals two. Tympanum visible, approximately one seventh the height of the eye. Supralabials six, the fifth and sixth being the suboculars. Ablepharine eye. Infralabials five. Postmental bordering five scales (mental, two primary chin-shields, and one infralabial on each side). Ventral scales smooth. MSR 23, SAD 56, SAV 57. Limbs with five digits; scales on soles of hands and feet smooth. Relative length of digits of manus III>IV>II>VI relative length of digits of pes IV>III>II=V>I. Finger-IV scales 9 (right side), Toe-IV scales 15 (right side). Tail long, robust and tapering smoothly.

Both in life and preservative, background color of flanks and upper side of head, neck, dorsum, legs and tail is coppery brown, with a darker dot in the anterior part of each scale. Posteriorly the tail is lighter, with disjunct dark speckles. A beige stripe, less than one scale wide, limited by the dorsal background color above and by a thin stripe of darker brown below (especially evident under the anterior part of eye), extends from the temporals and runs along the insertion of the arms. Areas below the dark brown stripe become lighter, until they reach the ventral side, which is beige. Presence of rows of light spots on the neck. Supralabials light beige anteriorly and posteriorly, with strong coppery brown markings in the middle. This pattern extends to the infralabials. Venter uniformly light-beige, as are the palmar regions of hands and feet.

Variation. Variaton in scalation and body measurements of the paratypes of Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. is reported in Table 5 . The majority of the paratypes agree entirely with the holotype , except regarding the contact between the prefrontals, which are separated in paratypes CAS 263325 and 263326.

Comparison with other south and southwestern African Panaspis .
As the molecular data provide evidence of the independence of the P. mocamedensis sp. nov. lineage from all other taxa, we here restrict our morphological comparisons to those named congeners occurring in Namibia and Angola . The extreme morphological conservatism of Panaspis limits diagnostic characters for most species (except P. cabindae and P. aff. breviceps ) to subtle features, chiefly related to coloration pattern. Comparing P. mocamedensis sp. nov. with P. cabindae and P. aff. breviceps , the newly described species can be easily distinguished by not having supranasals (present in P. cabindae ), by having an ablepharine eye (pre-ablepharine eye in P. cabindae and completely movable lower eyelids in P. aff. breviceps ), and by having the frontoparietals fused (divided in P. cabindae and in P. aff. breviceps ). In comparison with P. wahlbergi , P. mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished by its coloration, namely by the lack of the broad black lateral stripe and bordering ventrolateral white stripe extending from the supralabials through the ear to the groin (males) or terminating behind the shoulder (females). Panaspis mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from P. maculicollis on the basis of the lack of black patch extending from ear to just beyond the shoulder and by having a smaller count of midbody scale rows ( 23 to 24 inP. mocamedensis sp. nov.versus typically 26 inP. maculicollis ). P. mocamedensis sp. nov. can be distinguished from the newly described P. namibiana on the basis of the presence two or three vertical or diagonal rows of white spots on the neck and by having a smaller count of midbody scale rows ( 23 to 24 inP. mocamedensis sp. nov.versus usually more than 24 inP. namibiana ).

Distribution. The newly described species is currently only known from central Namibe Province (
). It is likely that the species occurs in other regions of the province where appropriate habitat is available, but further sampling is needed to confirm its presence.

Habitat and Natural History notes. The species is terrestrial and is typically found under leaf litter or other debris. It is only known from habitats represented by mosaics of steppes and savannah dominated by Mopane trees and sandy soils (
; Grandvaux-Barbosa 1973). Specimens from Virei were captured by day, but CAS 264266 was active under debris well after sunset.

Etymology. The specific epithet “ mocamedensis ” refers to the former name of Namibe Province (Moçâmedes), to which the species is apparently endemic. We propose the English vernacular name “Moçamedes Snake-Eyed Skink” and the Portuguese vernacular name of “Lagartixa da Manta-Morta de Moçâmedes”.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The Angolan population of P. aff. breviceps represents an interesting example of the northern intrusion of Central/West African lineages in the country, a pattern seen in many other herpetological groups (see
Marques et al. 2018
), and recently highlighted by Ernst et al. (2014, 2015). Ernst et al. (2014) recorded the presence of an undescribed species of Trichobatrachus in northern Angola . This taxon, morphologically indistinct from Trichobatrachys robustusBoulenger, 1900 , presented a considerable genetic divergence for the 12S and 16S mitochondrial genes, which may indicate the presence of a cryptic species (Ernst et al. 2014). A similar pattern was also presented by the discovery by the same team of representatives of Xenopus andrei Loumont, 1983
, in northwestern Angola (Ernst et al. 2015). Similar to the case of P. breviceps , the closest population of X. andrei lies 2,400 km north, in Gabon . However, the difficult taxonomic and nomenclatural history of P. breviceps , combined with the lack of molecular data to support any solid taxonomic decision, precludes us from making any more definitive conclusions as to the true identity of this population. As noted by
Soares et al. (2018)
and
Ceríaco et al. (2018a)
, the extreme morphological conservatism of the genus, makes morphology-only taxonomic decisions highly problematic and prone to errors. Dedicated surveys to the known areas of occurrence of this population are needed to collect additional specimens that will allow its taxonomic revision.

Despite being poorly known, P. cabindae is one of the most widespread species in the country. Its distribution extends from southwestern Congo to the Angolan Lunda provinces, and thence to southwestern Angola . The species has little genetic variation across its distribution, especially considering that it extends through quite different habitats, from low elevation areas to some of the higher areas of the Angolan central plateau, and also from the dense tropical forests of the Congo to the fringes of the most xeric areas in Namibe province. Its north to south distribution seems to follow the course of riparian areas and the escarpment, a pattern also seen in some species of the genus Trachylepis (Ceríaco et al. in prep.).

On the other hand, both P. maculicollis and P. wahlbergi are representatives of “Zambezian” species (sensu
Marques et al. 2018
), whose distribution finds its westernmost boundaries in southeastern Angola . The presence of other “Zambezian” species in central and southeastern Angola has already been noted by
Conradie et al. (2016)
and
Marques et al. (2018)
, and it is mainly explained by the somewhat open and homogeneous habitat that extends from the Central Plateau of Angola to parts of Zimbabwe , Mozambique , and northeastern South Africa . This region is situated at altitudes that vary between 1000 and 1500 meters above the sea level and are dominated by Miombo woodlands and savannahs without major geographic barriers, thus allowing the spread of species. Southeastern Angola remains one of the least explored areas in the country (
Conradie et al. 2016
;
Marques et al. 2018
), and it is expected that current and future surveys in the area will contribute to a better understanding of the phylogenetic and biogeographic affinities of the herpetofauna of the region, new species records for the country, and discovery of new species for science.

The distribution of Panaspis mocamedensis , sp. nov. in Namibe Province is coincident with one of the areas of highest reptile species richness and endemicity in the country (
Roll et al. 2017
;
Marques et al. 2018
). Its phylogenetic affinities to its recently described sister taxon, P. namibiana from neighbouring Namibia , suggests that the Cunene River may have acted as a barrier and promoted its separation and consequent speciation. The Cunene River’s role as a barrier is also observed in other herpetological taxa, as in the case of some taxa in the scincid genus Trachylepis (Ceríaco et al. in prep.) or in the gekkonid genus Rhoptropus ( Kuhn 2016 )
. However, the river appears to not have served as a barrier in other groups (
Heinicke et al. 2016
; Butler et al. in prep.), More data, from a wider taxonomic sampling, are needed to better understand the historical role of the Cunene.

As data on demography and other biological data are lacking, the conservation status of Angolan Panaspis must be based primarily on distributional data. With numerous localities across a large extent of occurrence, and presumably a large area of occupancy, IUCN Red List guidelines would imply a status of Least Concern for Panaspis cabindae and P. wahlbergi . These two species are also present in multiple sites within the Angolan protected areas network. The known distribution of P. maculicollis , which occurs in Angola marginally, lies within the Luenge-Luiana National Park boundaries, and it is widespread through Zambia , Namibia and Botswana , which also leads to a status of Least Concern. For the newly described endemic, P. mocamedensis sp. nov. , with only two known locali- ties, there is not enough data to infer its conservation status, and, therefore, the species should be considered of Data Deficient status. Due to the taxonomic uncertainties regarding P. aff. breviceps , the present data are insufficient to make any proper inference on conservation status.
